exercises.name: Barbell Squat
exercises.science: Compound movement activating 200+ muscles. Studies show squats increase testosterone and growth hormone by 25%. Depth to parallel or below maximizes glute activation.
exercises.form: Feet shoulder-width, bar on upper traps, descend until thighs parallel to ground, drive through heels

exercises.name: Deadlift
exercises.science: Highest muscle recruitment of any exercise. Research shows deadlifts improve bone density and functional strength. Engages 70% of skeletal muscle.
exercises.form: Hip-width stance, grip outside legs, neutral spine, drive hips forward

exercises.name: Bench Press
exercises.science: Primary chest builder. EMG studies show 30-45 degree decline maximizes pec activation. Progressive overload increases strength 5-10% monthly.
exercises.form: Retract scapula, arch lower back slightly, lower to mid-chest, press explosively

protein.science: Meta-analysis of 49 studies confirms 1.6g/kg optimizes muscle protein synthesis. Higher intake (2.2g/kg) beneficial during caloric deficit.

carbohydrates.science: Glycogen stores fuel high-intensity training. Research shows 5-7g/kg maximizes performance and recovery for athletes.

fats.science: Essential for hormone production. Studies show omega-3s reduce inflammation and improve recovery. Minimum 0.5g/kg for hormonal health.

sleep.science: Sleep deprivation reduces muscle protein synthesis by 18%. Growth hormone peaks during deep sleep. Studies show 8+ hours optimal for athletes.

hydration.science: 2% dehydration reduces performance by 10-20%. Electrolyte balance critical for muscle contraction and recovery.

restDays.science: Muscle growth occurs during rest. Research shows 48-72 hours needed for full muscle recovery. Overtraining increases cortisol and injury risk.
